key_insight: State-of-the-art vision-language models (VLMs) can act as reliable perceptual judges that replicate human binary preferences for compressed images, enabling human-aligned image compression without large-scale psychophysical data.
problem_solved: Conventional distortion metrics (e.g., MSE) and expensive human studies fail to capture human perceptual preferences; this work provides an automated, scalable judge that aligns compression models with human judgment.
method: Use pretrained VLMs to score or compare original vs. compressed image pairs (A/B preferences) by leveraging vision-language similarity/contrastive signals.
Convert VLM judgments into a perceptual objective or ranking loss that guides training of compression models, optionally using frozen VLM embeddings or differentiable similarity measures.
Validate alignment by measuring correlation with human preference studies and comparing rate–distortion trade-offs against standard perceptual losses and baselines.
impact: Provides a practical, scalable path to train and evaluate compression models that match human perception, reducing reliance on costly psychophysical datasets and improving perceived quality at given bitrates.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: original/compressed image pair → VLM judge → perceptual loss → compression model training
Bar chart or scatter plot: correlation of VLM scores vs. human A/B preferences compared to MSE/LPIPS
Image grid: side-by-side compressed examples (MSE vs. VLM-aligned) annotated with VLM scores and human votes
Icon set: reduced annotation cost, better perceived quality (eye icon), model-in-the-loop (gear + VLM logo)
paper_title: VLIC: Vision-Language Models As Perceptual Judges for Human-Aligned Image Compression
paper_authors: Kyle Sargent, Ruiqi Gao, Philipp Henzler, Charles Herrmann, Aleksander Holynski
